case_data.name: Namisnak v. Uber Technologies, Inc.
case_data.plaintiff_description: Three individuals from New Orleans who use electric wheelchairs to get around.
case_data.summary:
On October 26, 2017, three individuals from New Orleans, represented by private counsel, filed a complaint in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against Uber Technologies, Inc. and its subsidiary, Rasier LLC (Collectively, “Uber”). The plaintiffs alleged that Uber violated its legal obligations under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), the California Disabled Persons Act (CDPA), and California’s Unfair Competition Law (UCL) by failing to provide wheelchair-accessible rides through the Uber app. The complaint also included a theory that Uber was a “place of public accommodation” because it had organized a concert at a secret location that was accessible only by Uber. The case was originally assigned to District Judge Maxine M. Chesney, but shortly thereafter the case was related to a similar lawsuit (Crawford v. Uber Technologies, Inc.) and reassigned to District Judge Richard Seeborg, who was presiding over the Crawford case.

Uber moved to compel the New Orleans Plaintiffs to arbitration on January 23, 2018. They argued that the plaintiffs couldn’t show they had been injured because they hadn’t actually downloaded the Uber app and so lacked standing under Title III of the ADA. They further argued that, if Plaintiffs did have standing, they should be prevented from avoiding the arbitration agreement in the Uber app’s terms and conditions under a theory of equitable estoppel—essentially that the plaintiffs couldn’t seek to benefit from an agreement while refusing to abide by its terms. One of the three New Orleans Plaintiffs had actually downloaded the Uber app.

On April 13, 2018, Judge Seeborg granted Uber’s motion with respect to that Plaintiff but denied it with respect to the other Plaintiff because Uber’s argument was based on contract law, and Plaintiffs sought to enforce the ADA against Uber, not the terms and conditions agreement. 315 F. Supp. 3d 1124.

With their claims surviving, the plaintiffs amended their complaint on May 8, 2018  to remove the California state law claims (in response to a ruling in the Crawford case). Uber initiated an appeal to the ruling on the motion to compel arbitration on May 16, 2018 and filed a motion to dismiss the plaintiffs’ first amended complaint on May 22, 2018. In the motion, Uber argued that the plaintiffs never formally requested the modification they are seeking, a requirement under the ADA. Uber also disputed that it was a place of public accommodation under the ADA simply because it had organized a concert. 

On July 17, 2018 the plaintiffs agreed to consolidate their fact discovery with the Crawford case’s, but each set of plaintiffs continued to file motions separately and remained docketed separately.

On October 3, 2018, Judge Seeborg granted Uber’s motion to dismiss with respect to the plaintiffs’ public accommodation theory—holding that the concert venue was the public accommodation, not Uber—and with respect to the “formal request” requirement. The complaint survived on the auxiliary aid and removal of barriers provisions of the ADA, and the plaintiffs were given leave to amend their complaint to properly allege that they had requested that Uber modify its service. The plaintiffs filed a second amended complaint on October 11, 2018. 2018 WL 7200717.

The parties jointly proposed orders to stay the proceedings for 12 months on October 30, 2018, which Judge Seeborg granted on November 5. On October 24, 2019, the Jackson Plaintiffs and Uber jointly proposed an order to stay their proceedings for an additional 6 months, which the court granted the following day.

On December 17, 2019, Uber filed a motion to dismiss the New Orleans Plaintiffs’ second amended complaint. They argued that the Plaintiffs lacked a private right of action under Title III because they didn’t allege they were being presently discriminated against (since they had never downloaded the Uber app). They also argued that Plaintiffs’ requested modifications were unreasonable and that Plaintiffs didn’t allege any facts to suggest they were denied auxiliary aids and that the complaint didn’t implicate any failure to remove barriers. 

Judge Seeborg denied in part and granted in part the motion to dismiss on March 12, 2020. He held that the ADA provides a right of action to anyone who has reasonable grounds to believe a person is “about to be” subjected to discrimination on the basis of disability, which does not require the Plaintiffs to be active users of the Uber app. He granted Uber’s motion with regard to the auxiliary aid and removal of barriers theories, holding that those provisions did not apply to individuals with mobility impairments. 444 F. Supp. 3d 1136.

On May 14, 2020, Uber’s appeal of the District Court’s ruling on the motion to compel arbitration was argued in the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit before Circuit Judges J. Clifford Wallace and Ryan D. Nelson as well as District Judge Frederic Block of the Eastern District of New York sitting by designation. On August 24, 2020, in a decision authored by Judge Nelson, the Ninth Circuit affirmed the District Court’s ruling. The Court held that the plaintiffs did not need to go through the motions of a “futile gesture” to obtain standing under the ADA and that the terms and conditions did not apply because the plaintiffs were never party to that contractual agreement. 971 F.3d 1088.

For the remainder of the case, the New Orleans and Jackson Plaintiffs generally filed identical motions but the cases remained docketed separately. Uber in turn filed separate, identical motions in each case. The court’s orders addressed both sets of plaintiffs together but appeared in both dockets. 

The remainder of this case’s summary can be found in the Crawford v. Uber Technologies, Inc. entry on the clearinghouse.
case_data.summary_short: A group of New Orleans-based plaintiffs who use wheelchairs to get around filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California asking the court to require Uber to provide wheelchair-accessible vehicle service in their city. The lawsuit alleged that, because Uber provided access to wheelchair-accessible vehicles on its app in other comparably sized cities, it should be required to do so in the plaintiffs' city as well pursuant to the Americans with Disabilities Act. After a bench trial, the District Court judge decided the plaintiffs failed to show that this suggested modification was reasonable, and ruled that Uber was not required to offer wheelchair-accessible vehicle service under the ADA. The case is currently on appeal to the Ninth Circuit.

9  own or lease vehicles to be subject to section 12184.” Access Living, 351 F. Supp. at 1159. Their 
10  citations to Toomer v. City Cab, 443 F.3d 1191, 1195 (10th Cir. 2006), and Noel v. New York City 
11  Taxi & Limousine Comm’n, 687 F.3d 63, 65 (2d Cir. 2012), are misguided; not only are those 
12  cases not binding authority, but they also did not even consider claims presented under section 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  12184(b)(2). Put differently, even if defendants were correct that they are not subject to sections 
Cif
t al
cC 14  12184(b)(3) and (5), they have not presented any evidence that they would not be subject to 
i
strof 
Dict  15  section 12184(b)(2), as discussed above. As was held in a related case, “Uber’s fixation on 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  whether WAVs are specifically required by statute is unavailing in light of the broad language of 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  the ADA.” Crawford, 2018 WL 1116725, at *4. “A covered entity under Section 12184 is subject 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  not just to the narrow requirements associated with the purchase of new vehicles, but the statute’s 
19  broader anti-discrimination mandate.” Id. 
20  C.  Failure to Provide Auxiliary Aids  
21  Defendants next argue plaintiffs have failed to allege plausibly a failure to provide 
22  auxiliary aids. Section 12184 requires covered entities to “provide auxiliary aids and services,” 42 
23  U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2)(B), to disabled individuals, unless doing so would “fundamentally alter” the 
24  nature of the provided service or “result in an undue burden,” id. § 12182(b)(2)(A)(iii). Plaintiffs 
25 
 
26  4 Defendants argue in their reply brief that plaintiffs have forfeited their claim to equivalent 
service by failing to address it in the response brief. Plaintiffs, however, do address the “equivalent 
27  service” issue. See Plaintiffs’ Memorandum in Opposition, ECF No. 100, at 14 n.78. 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
8 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 9 of 12
 
1  allege UberWAV is an “auxiliary aid or service” which defendants were obligated to, and did not, 
2  provide. Defendants argue instead that this provision of the ADA is only intended to protect the 
3  hearing and vision impaired—a group into which plaintiffs do not fall. In support of their position, 
4  defendants cite a Department of Justice rule which expressly excludes individuals with mobility 
5  impairments from the “auxiliary aids and services” provisions of the ADA. See 56 Fed. Reg. 
6  35,544-01, 35,566 (July 26, 1991) (“DOJ Rule”). 
7  The DOJ Rule was issued after a notice-and-comment process and thus is owed Chevron 
8  deference. Chevron U.S.A., Inc. v. Nat. Res. Def. Council, Inc., 467 U.S. 837, 842 (1984). “First, 
9  always, is the question whether Congress has directly spoken to the precise question at issue. If the 
10  intent of Congress is clear, that is the end of the matter; for the court, as well as the agency, must 
11  give effect to the unambiguously expressed intent of Congress.” Id. at 842–43. If congressional 
12  intent is not clear, the court must determine at step two “whether the agency’s answer is based on 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  a permissible construction of the statute.” Id. at 843 (emphasis added). The agency’s interpretation 
Cif
t al
cC 14  must be deferred to unless it is unreasonable. Id. at 845. 
i
strof 
Dict  15  At step one, the first guide to Congress’s intent is the text of the statute. The ADA reads, in 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  relevant part: 
d Srn   
ee 17 
th The term “auxiliary aids and services” includes— 
nirt
Uo (A) qualified interpreters or other effective methods of making aurally 
N 18 
delivered materials available to individuals with hearing impairments; 
19  (B)  qualified  readers,  taped  texts,  or  other  effective  methods  of 
making  visually  delivered  materials  available  to  individuals  with 
20  visual impairments; 
(C) acquisition or modification of equipment or devices; and 
21 
(D) other similar services and actions. 
 
22 
42 U.S.C. § 12103(1). 
23 
  In interpreting this text, each party offers a canon of statutory interpretation. Plaintiffs 
24 
employ the rule against surplusage, which they say dictates that, if subpart (A) governs individuals 
25 
with hearing impairments, and (B) those with visual impairments, then (C) and (D) must be about 
26 
other disabled individuals, such as those with limited mobility, or they would be duplicative of (A) 
27 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
9 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 10 of 12
 
1  and (B). Defendants bring noscitur a sociis to the table, which they say requires subparts (C) and 
2  (D) to be interpreted in the context of the accompanying words, i.e. subparts (A) and (B), which 
3  limit the scope to individuals with hearing and visual impairments. Put differently, plaintiffs argue 
4  each subpart covers a type of disability; defendants assign each subpart to a means of 
5  accommodating disability. These statutory interpretations are equally reasonable. Substantive 
6  disagreements aside, then, these competing conclusions evince merely that the text is ambiguous. 
7  While other parts of the ADA—including section 12184(b)(2)(A), which covers 
8  “reasonable modifications,” as discussed above—contemplate accommodations which must be 
9  provided to those with mobility impairments, they do not foreclose that section 12184(b)(2)(B), 
10  which covers “auxiliary aids and services,” does so as well. Section 12184(b)(2)(A) is not 
11  explicitly or exclusively about individuals with mobility impairments. It could conceivably 
12  encompass the “reasonable modifications” necessary to accommodate those with hearing and 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  visual impairments as well. Neither party has cited any statutory text, legislative history, or 
Cif
t al
cC 14  caselaw to the contrary. Therefore, section 12184(b)(2)(B) may be similarly wide-reaching. 
i
strof 
Dict  15  The legislative history cited by plaintiffs also does not provide clarity. The Ninth Circuit 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  allows legislative history to be consulted “cautiously” at step one of Chevron analysis but 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  precludes its use to “enforce a principle…that has no statutory reference point.” United Cook Inlet 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Drift Ass’n v. Nat’l Marine Fisheries Serv., 837 F.3d 1055, 1063 n.1 (9th Cir. 2016) (internal 
19  citations and quotations omitted). One cited portion of the legislative history indicates section 
20  12184(b), generally, applies to individuals with mobility impairments. H.R. Rep. No. 101-336, at 
21  401 (1990). It does not, however, specifically discuss the “auxiliary aids and services” 
22  requirement. Another cited provision clarifies that the examples provided in section 12103(1) are 
23  just examples, not an exhaustive list of “auxiliary aids and services.” Id. at 161. Again, however, 
24  that does not clarify how far past the list the term does extend. The final cited provision is perhaps 
25  plaintiffs’ best case: it uses the example of how a bookstore must be made accessible to 
26  wheelchair-bound individuals in the context of defining “auxiliary aids and services.” Id. at 161–
27  62. However, even this piece of history does not go so far as to state affirmatively that “auxiliary 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
10 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 11 of 12
 
1  aids and services” are not limited to hearing- and vision-impaired individuals. It is hardly “clear 
2  evidence” which “illuminate[s] ambiguous text.” Milner v. Dep’t of Navy, 562 U.S. 562, 572 
3  (2011). See also Azar v. Allina Health Servs., 139 S. Ct. 1804, 1814 (2019) (declining to follow 
4  legislative history which was “ambiguous at best”). Thus, congressional intent is not clear. 
5  Moving on to Chevron step two, the DOJ Rule must be deferred to unless it is 
6  unreasonable. The Rule clearly provides that the provisions of the ADA encompassing “auxiliary 
7  aids and services” do not apply to individuals with mobility impairments because they are covered 
8  by other parts of the ADA, such as reasonable modifications. See DOJ Rule. Because the ADA 
9  requires “auxiliary aids and services” to be offered proactively, while “reasonable modifications” 
10  must be requested, plaintiffs point out the DOJ Rule creates two types of disabilities: those that 
11  must be affirmatively accommodated (hearing and vision impairments), and those that need not be 
12  accommodated absent a request (all other disabilities). While this system may not be what 
a 
rt ni
ouor 13  plaintiffs prefer, “or even the reading the court would have reached if the question initially had 
Cif
t al
cC 14  arisen in a judicial proceeding,” Chevron, 467 U.S. at 843 n.11, plaintiffs have not explained how 
i
strof 
Dict  15  it is unreasonable. The DOJ might reasonably have considered, for example, that those who suffer 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  from hearing and vision impairments may have more difficulty even communicating their need for 
 Sn 
dr
ee 17  an accommodation than those with other disabilities. It seems the DOJ simply chose “among 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  competing reasonable interpretations” of the ADA. Michigan v. E.P.A., 135 S. Ct. 2699, 2708 
19  (2015). The courts have no authority to second-guess it. Thus plaintiffs, as a matter of law, cannot 
20  plausibly allege an “auxiliary aids and services” claim. 
21  Finally, defendants argue plaintiffs have failed to allege plausibly a failure to remove 
22  barriers, 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2)(C), or a failure to communicate, 49 C.F.R. § 37.167(f). Plaintiffs 
23  did not respond to those arguments. Furthermore, when defendants’ reply indicated they 
24  considered plaintiffs’ nonresponses to amount to forfeiture of the arguments, plaintiffs did not 
25  move to clarify if they did not intend to do so. Plaintiffs’ theories regarding failure to remove 
26  barriers and failure to communicate are therefore dismissed. See Ardente, Inc. v. Shanley, No. 07-
27  cv-04479, 2010 WL 546485, at *6 (N.D. Cal. Feb. 10, 2010) (“Plaintiff fails to respond to this 
28  ORDER 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
11 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 102   Filed 03/13/20   Page 12 of 12
 
1  argument and therefore concedes it through silence.”). 
2  V.  CONCLUSION 
3    For the reasons set forth above, the motion to dismiss is granted in part and denied in part. 
4  Plaintiffs have plausibly alleged a private right of action and a requested reasonable modification. 
5  However, they cannot plausibly allege a failure to provide auxiliary aids and have failed to 
6  respond to defendants’ arguments regarding a failure to remove barriers or to communicate. Those 
7  theories are therefore dismissed with prejudice. With these modifications, the SAC shall proceed 
8  as the operative complaint. 
9   
10  IT IS SO ORDERED. 
11

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 2 of 25
 
1  I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
2  1.  STEPHAN NAMISNAK is a person with a disability who lives in New Orleans, 
3  Louisiana. MR. NAMISNAK has Muscular Dystrophy.  
4  2.  FRANCIS  FALLS  is  a  person  with  a  disability  who  lives  in  New  Orleans, 
5  Louisiana. MR. FALLS is afflicted with paraplegia as a result of a spinal cord injury. MR. FALLS 
6  is also missing his right arm.  
7  3.  MITCHELL MIRAGLIA is a person with a disability who lives in New Orleans, 
8  Louisiana. MR. MIRAGLIA is a quadriplegic who has cerebral palsy and requires a wheelchair 
9  for mobility.  
10  4.  Each of the named Plaintiffs use an electric wheelchair to get from place to place. 
11  Plaintiffs  can  do  practically  everything  a  non-disabled  person  can  do  with  the  appropriate 
12  accommodations for their disability – work, travel, and enjoy life. However, Plaintiffs are not able 
13  to drive. As a result, Plaintiffs primarily rely on public transportation to get around the New 
14  Orleans metro area.  
15  5.  Defendants  Uber  Technologies,  Inc.  and  Rasier,  LLC  (collectively,  “Uber”) 
16  provide a mobile-phone app service that allows users to call a car to drive them from point A to 
17  point B for a fee. The app also allows people who own cars to sign up as drivers to provide those 
18  rides.  
19  6.  Uber is operating a nation-wide demand-responsive transportation system.  
20  7.  In  some  cities,  Uber  has  options  for  disabled  users  who  use  wheelchairs.  For 
21  example, if a user is in San Francisco, Portland, or Washington, D.C., they are shown an icon in the 
22  Uber app for “Uber Access.” By selecting that icon, those users shown options – UberASSIST 
23  and/or UberWAV. UberASSIST allows a person with a disability to hail a driver who has been 
24  specifically trained to assist riders into vehicles and who can accommodate folding wheelchairs, 
- 2 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 3 of 25
 
1  walkers,  and  scooters.  UberWAV  allows  a  person  with  a  disability  to  hail  a  driver  with  a 
2  wheelchair-accessible vehicle. 
3  8.  Due to Plaintiffs’ need for a heavy electric wheelchair that cannot be folded up and 
4  placed in a car’s trunk, they are unable to utilize UberASSIST. However, Plaintiffs could benefit 
5  and utilize UberWAV – if it was available in New Orleans.  
6  9.  Unfortunately, Defendants have refused to make the UberWAV program available to 
7  New Orleans users. 
8  10.  As a result of Uber’s refusal to make UberWAV available in New Orleans, persons 
9  with disabilities in New Orleans have no ability to call an accessible vehicle through the Uber app 
10  that will accommodate their needs. Even if there are drivers on the road who have such a vehicle or 
11  training, there is no way for a New Orleans users to find an UberWAV vehicle through the app. For 
12  this reason, Plaintiffs are excluded from Uber’s transportation services and application.  
13  11.  Under the Americans With Disabilities Act, Uber is required to make reasonable 
14  modifications to its services, provide auxiliary aids and services, and remove barriers that deter 
15  persons with disabilities. Uber is plainly able to do these things – as evidenced by the fact that they 
16  offer UberWAV elsewhere. Furthermore, Uber’s ability to revise their app is evident by their 
17  periodic special promotions in which they alter the app to connect users to puppies, cake, and 
18  donuts for a single day.  For example, on the evening of the filing of this Complaint, Uber is hosting 
19  a free, “secret” music concert in New Orleans that can only be reached by taking an Uber – and is 
20  therefore completely inaccessible to Plaintiffs. Despite their clear ability to alter the app, defendants 
21  have chosen not to provide sufficient wheelchair-accessible services in New Orleans, Louisiana.  
22  12.  As  such,  Uber  has  violated  their  legal  obligations  under  the  Americans  With 
23  Disabilities  Act  (“ADA”),  42  U.S.C.  §  12181,  et  seq.,  the  California  Disabled  Persons  Act, 
24 
- 3 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 4 of 25
 
1  California Civil Code § 54 et seq. (“CDPA”), and California's Unfair Competition Law (“UCL”) 
2  (Business & Professions Code § 17200 et seq.)  
3  13.  According to the U.S. Department of Justice, Title III lawsuits over inaccessible 
4  transportation go “to the very heart of the ADA’s goals ‘to assure equality of opportunity, full 
5  participation, independent living, and economic self-sufficiency’ for individuals with disabilities.”1 
6  Plaintiffs seek to vindicate the promises of federal and state law. 
7  II. JURISDICTION AND PARTIES 
8  14.  Jurisdiction: This is an action for relief pursuant to Title III of the Americans With 
9  Disabilities Act, 42 U.S.C. § 12181 et seq. This Court is vested with original jurisdiction pursuant 
10  to 28 U.S.C. § 1331 and 1343. This court is vested with supplemental jurisdiction over Plaintiff’s 
11  state  law  claims  pursuant  to  28  U.S.C.  §  1367  as  this  claim  arises  out  of  the  same  case  or 
12  controversy as the federal claim. 
13  15.  Intradistrict Assignment: Because the claims described infra arose in the County of 
14  San Francisco, this case should be assigned to the San Francisco or Oakland Division of the 
15  Northern District of California per Local Rule 3-2(d). 
16  16.  Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1391(b) because Defendants 
17  are headquartered in San Francisco, California.    
18  17.  Plaintiff  STEPHAN  NAMISNAK  is  a  citizen  and  resident  of  New  Orleans, 
19  Louisiana. He uses an electric wheelchair for mobility. He is disabled within the meaning of the 
20  ADA. Mr. Namisnak’s motorized wheelchair cannot be folded into the trunk of a car. 
21  18.  Plaintiff FRANCIS FALLS is a citizen and resident of New Orleans, Louisiana. He 
22  uses an electric wheelchair for mobility. He is disabled within the meaning of the ADA. He requires 
23 
                                                 
24  1 National Federation of the Blind of California v. Uber Technologies, Inc., N. D. Cal. 14-cv-4086, 
R. Doc. 29 at 4. 
- 4 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 5 of 25
 
1  wheelchair accessible vehicles for transportation. He uses a motorized wheelchair that cannot be 
2  folded into the trunk of a car. 
3  19.  Plaintiff  MITCHELL  MIRAGLIA  is  a  citizen  and  resident  of  New  Orleans, 
4  Louisiana. He uses an electric wheelchair for mobility. He is disabled within the meaning of the 
5  ADA. Mr. Miraglia’s motorized wheelchair cannot be folded into the trunk of a car. 
6  20.  Defendant UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC. is a foreign corporation, organized 
7  under the laws of the  State of Delaware,  with  its principal  place of  business  located in  San 
8  Francisco, California. Uber Technologies, Inc.’s subsidiary, Rasier, LLC is registered with the 
9  Louisiana Secretary of State as charter number 41604705F.  
10  21.  Defendant RASIER, LLC is a foreign corporation, organized under the laws of the 
11  State of Delaware, with its principal place of business located in San Francisco, California. Rasier, 
12  LLC is registered with the Louisiana Secretary of State as charter number 41585719Q. 
13  22.  Together,  Defendants  provide  an  extremely  popular  vehicles-for-hire  service 
14  whereby Uber drivers pick up customers and provide them with transportation in an automobile. 
15  Defendants  do not provide vehicles-for-hire services to mobility-impaired consumers  in  New 
16  Orleans  who  require  wheelchair-accessible  transportation  vehicles  that  can  accommodate  an 
17  electric wheelchair.  
18  III.  FACTS 
19  Defendants Operate a Vehicle-for-Hire Transportation System in New Orleans  
20  23.  Uber pioneered the vehicle-for-hire market across the United States. Anyone with 
21  access  to  a  smartphone  can  request  travel  services  from  Uber.  Uber’s  customers  use  a 
22  smartphone application to locate, schedule, and pay for their travel. Consumers enter into contracts 
23  and  business  relationships  by contacting  Uber  via electronic notification  using an  application 
24  downloaded to their smartphone (hereinafter known as the “Uber Application”). Upon receipt of a 
- 5 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 6 of 25
 
1  request from a customer, Uber then dispatch a driver and vehicle to pick up the customer for 
2  transport to their desired location. Through use of the Uber Application, consumers agree to pay 
3  for the services with a credit card via their smartphone.  These charges may include safety fees, 
4  municipal fees, and other fees.   
5  24.  Unlike taxi vehicles in New Orleans, where the fare rate is set by the New Orleans 
6  City Council, the fare rates for Uber customers is set by Uber according to Uber’s confidential and 
7  secret algorithm. Pursuant to Uber’s confidential and secret algorithm, Uber can charge more for its 
8  services depending on the time of day, number of drivers, or estimated profitability. The decision 
9  on the price displayed on the Uber Application is set solely by Uber.  
10  25.  Upon information and belief, Uber can deduct fare from a driver if a rider complains 
11  about his/her safety, the professionalism of the driver, cleanliness of the vehicle, or incorrect 
12  designation and/or charges, among other issues.  
13  26.  Uber requires that riders provide a “rating” of their driver prior to the next trip; Uber 
14  requests that drivers provide a “rating” of their rider prior to the next trip. These rating facilitate the 
15  transportation experience and provide valuable data and information to Uber.  
16  27.  Uber has the ability and option to temporarily or permanently deactivate a rider’s 
17  account. 
18  28.  Uber has the ability and option to temporarily or permanently deactivate a driver’s 
19  account.  
20  29.  Uber has the ability to charge a rider a “post-ride” fee (i.e. a cleaning fee) at the 
21  request of a rider.  
22  30.  In the New Orleans area, Uber has the ability to “geo-lock” certain locations and 
23  prevent drivers from visiting those geographic areas.  
24  31.  Upon information and belief, in the New Orleans area Uber has actually utilized its 
- 6 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 7 of 25
 
1  ability to “geo-lock” certain locations. 
2  32.  Upon  information  and  belief,  Uber  has  the  ability  to  exclude  drivers  based  on 
3  personal features – such as how many years they have had a driver’s license in the United States.  
4  33.  Upon information and belief, Uber has a policy against allowing individuals who 
5  have had a driver’s license in the United States for less than one year for driving for Uber in the 
6  New Orleans area.  
7  34.  Upon information and belief, Uber has (or had in the recent past) a policy against 
8  allowing individuals with non-Louisiana license plates from driving for Uber in the New Orleans 
9  area.  
10  35.  Upon information and belief, Uber assists, or has assted, drivers with purchasing 
11  new cars via co-signing leases and/or ownership agreements (i.e.   
12  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5-Jx6G68Wpo). 
13  36.  Uber’s  prior  CEO  wrote  on  Uber’s  official  blog:  “We  are  ‘Everyone's  Private 
14  Driver.’ We are Uber and we're rolling out a transportation system in a city near you.” 
15  37.  Upon  information  and  belief,  would-be  drivers  are  required  to  pass  a  “city 
16  knowledge test” and attend a brief interview with an employee of Uber. Upon information and 
17  belief, Uber has previously referred to itself as an “On– Demand Car Service.” 
18  38.  As one court summed it up:  
19  Uber is deeply involved in marketing its transportation services, qualifying and 
selecting drivers, regulating and monitoring their performance, disciplining (or 
20  terminating)  those  who  fail  to  meet  standards,  and  setting  prices.2 
 
21  39.  Uber has explicitly declared itself to be a “transportation system” over and over 
22  again. A few examples: 
23  A.  Decemember 5, 2011: “We are ‘Everyone's Private Driver.’ We are Uber 
24                                                   
2 O'Connor v. Uber Techs., Inc., 82 F. Supp. 3d 1133, 1137 (N.D. Cal. 2015).  
- 7 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 8 of 25
 
1  and  we're  rolling  out  a  transportation  system  in  a  city  near  you.”3 
 
2  B.  March 8, 2012: “So today could eventually be considered historical for 
the city of Angels because it is today that Uber LA  is officially rolling 
3  out its transportation system in this fine city.  Now, how is some on-
demand town car service calling itself a transportation system? And 
4  how are a bunch of limos going to make this city better?  We’ve got a 
bunch of examples for you, but let me start with this: for every well 
5  utilized UberCar on the road, we’re taking 6 cars off the road and out of 
parking garages.”4  
6     
C.  June 8, 2012: Uber seeks to deliver the “World’s Finest Transportation 
7  System”5 
 
8  D.  August  2,  2013:  “We're  finally  giving  this  city  the transportation 
system that it deserves.”6  
9   
E.  Uber engineers’ code “will contribute to accelerating the growth of a 
10  transportation system that will directly affect the lives of more than 
three million people every single day.”7   
11   
F.  August  22:  2014:  Uber  “provides  the  city  with  a  more  efficient 
12  transportation system.”8   
 
13  G.  December 14, 2014: “Uber platform allows for safe and reliable rides, 
supporting and extending New Jersey’s public transportation system.”9
14     
 
15  H.  June  17,  2015:  “Uber  is  proud  to  support  the  Taxi  and  Limousine 
Commission’s  revised  rules  which  allow  tech  innovation  to  continue 
16  making New York City’s transportation system more progressive for all 
riders and drivers and ensure that drivers and passengers are protected.”10 
17   
I.  July 22, 2015: “Together, we can build an even better, more reliable 
18  transportation  system.  This  is  great  news  for  all  New  Yorkers, 
including Uber riders and drivers.”11

1  92.  Title III of the ADA prohibits discrimination against persons with disabilities by 
2  places  of  public  accommodation  and  by  private  entities  providing  certain  services,  including 
3  specified public transportation services. Spector v. Norwegian Cruise Line Ltd., 545 U.S. 119, 128 
4  (2005) (“Title III of the ADA prohibits discrimination against the disabled in the full and equal 
5  enjoyment of public accommodations, 42 U.S.C. § 12182(a), and public transportation services, § 
6  12184(a).”); 42 U.S.C. § 12182 (“Prohibition of discrimination by public accommodations”); 42 
7  U.S .C. § 12184 (“Prohibition of discrimination in specified public transportation services provided 
8  by private entities”). 
9  93.  “The term ‘specified public transportation’ means transportation by bus, rail, or any 
10  other conveyance (other than by aircraft) that provides the general public with general or special 
11  service (including charter service) on a regular and continuing basis.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(10). 
12  Public transportation services include “demand responsive systems,” which means “any system of 
13  providing transportation of individuals by a vehicle, other than a system which is a fixed route 
14  system.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(3). 
15  94.  In  addition,  regulations  promulgated  by  the  United  States  Secretary  of 
16  Transportation provide that: “No entity shall discriminate against an individual with a disability in 
17  connection with the provision of transportation service.” 49 C.F.R. § 37.5(a).  
18  95.  Defendants provide a demand responsive transportation system as defined by 42 
19  U.S.C. § 12181. Defendants have been held to be a covered entity under Title III of the ADA. 
20  See, e.g., Ramos v. Uber Technologies, 2015 WL 758087 at *5-6 (W.D. Tex., Feb. 20, 2015). 
21  96.  Under Section 12184(a)(2) of the ADA, discrimination includes the failure of an 
22  entity to: 
23  (A)   make reasonable modifications consistent with those required under section 
12182(b)(2)(A)(ii) of this title; 
24  (B)   provide auxiliary aids and services consistent with the requirements of section 
12182(b)(2)(A)(iii) of this title; and

this title and with the requirements of section 12183(a)(2) of this title;

ensures  a  level  of  service  to  individuals  with  disabilities,  including  individuals  who  use

wheelchairs, equivalent to the level of service provided to individuals without disabilities.”

characteristics:

(f) Reservations capability (if the system is demand responsive);

12  recover minimum statutory damages under the CPDA. 
13  121.  Plaintiffs are deterred  from patronizing Defendants’ transportation services as  a 
14  result of their actual knowledge of the violations stated above. 
15  122.  Pursuant to the remedies, procedures, and rights set forth in California law, including 
16  Cal. Civ. Code § 54, Plaintiff prays for judgment as set forth below. 
17  COUNT III – VIOLATION OF CALIFORNIA’S UNFAIR COMPETITION LAW  
18  123.  Plaintiffs re-allege and incorporate by reference the above allegations set forth in the 
19  Complaint as if fully set forth herein. 
20  124.  California's  Unfair  Competition  Law  (“UCL”)  (Business  &  Professions  Code  § 
21  17200  et  seq.) bars  “unfair  competition,”  which  includes  any  “unlawful,  unfair  or  fraudulent 
22  business act or practice and unfair, deceptive, untrue or misleading advertising.” 
23  125.  In passing the UCL, the legislature “intended to permit courts to enjoin ongoing 
24  wrongful business conduct in whatever context such activity might occur.” Comm. on Children’s 
- 23 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 24 of 25
 
1  Television, Inc. v. Gen. Foods Corp., 35 Cal. 3d 197, 210 (1983). 
2  126.  The UCL  “‘borrows’ violations of other laws  and treats  these violations, when 
3  committed pursuant to business activity, as unlawful practices independently actionable under [the 
4  UCL].” Farmers Ins. Exch. v. Super. Ct., 2 Cal. 4th 377, 383 (1992); Clerkin v. MyLife.com, Inc., 
5  No. C 11– 00527 CW, 2011 WL 3607496, at *6 (N.D. Cal. Aug. 16, 2011) (“Violation of almost 
6  any federal, state or local law may serve as the basis for a UCL claim.”). 
7  127.  Defendants business practices described above are unfair competition under the UCL 
8  because they violate the ADA and CDPA. 
9  128.  Defendants business practices described above are unfair competition also because 
10  Defendants’  failure  to  provide  accommodations  gives  them  an  unfair  advantage  relative  to 
11  traditional taxi cab companies.  
12  129.  As a result of Defendants unfair competition business practices described above, 
13  Plaintiffs have suffered injury in fact and have lost money. For example, they have been forced to 
14  take more expensive taxi cabs, thus losing money.  
15  V. JURY DEMAND 
16  130.  Plaintiffs request a trial by jury.  
17  VI. RELIEF REQUESTED 
18    WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs demand judgment against Defendants, and request the following 
19  relief: 
20  A.  that this Court declare that Defendants’ policies, procedures, and services have been 
21  provided in a discriminatory manner which violates the ADA, the California Disabled 
22  Persons Act, and California’s Business & Professions Code § 17200;  
23  B.  that this Court declare that Defendants’ violations of the anti-discrimination statutes of 
24  California were intentional; 
- 24 -   COMPLAINT            
 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-JSC   Document 1   Filed 10/26/17   Page 25 of 25
 
1  C.  that this Court Order injunctive relief to require Defendants to bring their transportation 
2  service into compliance and remain in compliance with state and federal anti-discrimination 
3  statutes;  
4  D.  that this Court award damages in restitution to Plaintiffs;  
5  E.  that this Court award reasonable attorneys’ fees and costs (including expert fees) and other 
6  expenses of suit; and    
7  F.  that this Court award such other and further relief as it deems necessary, just, proper, and 
8  appropriate.   
9  Respectfully submitted, this the twenty-sixth day of October, 2017, 
 
10  By Plaintiffs, by and through their counsel, 
 
11 
BIZER & DEREUS, LLC

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 1 of 11
 
1

7  UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8  NORTHERN DISTRICT OF CALIFORNIA 
9   
STEPHAN NAMISNAK, et al., 
10  Case No.  17-cv-06124-RS    
Plaintiffs,   
11   
v.  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND 
 a 12    DENYING IN PART UBER’S MOTION 
 rtni UBER TECHNOLOGIES, INC., et al.,  TO DISMISS 
ouor 13 
t Calif Defendants.   
cC 14 
i
strof     
Dict  15    I. INTRODUCTION   
s ri
et
tatDis 16    This case involves a dispute over the application of the Americans with Disabilities Act 
d Srn 
ee 17  (“ADA”) to the Uber rideshare service. Invoking federal question jurisdiction, plaintiffs Stephan 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Namisnak and Francis Falls (collectively, “Plaintiffs”) filed this action against defendants Uber 
19  Technologies, Inc. and Raiser, LLC (collectively, “Uber”). 28 U.S.C. § 1331. Uber moves to 
20  dismiss Plaintiffs’ First Amended Complaint (“FAC”) in its entirety for failure to state a claim 
21  under section 12184 or section 12182. 42 U.S.C. §§ 12182, 12184. Uber argues Plaintiffs fail to 
22  state a claim under section 12184 because they have not requested an accommodation, as required 
23  under section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii) (referenced by way of section 12184(b)(2)(A)). Uber further 
24  argues Plaintiffs fail to state a claim under section 12182 because Uber does not qualify as a place 
25  of public accommodation. For the reasons set forth below, the motion to dismiss is denied in part 
26  and granted in part, with leave to amend.  
27 
28 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 2 of 11
 
1  II. BACKGROUND1 
2    Uber operates a vehicle-for-hire service that uses a mobile phone application (the “Uber 
3  App”). The Uber App allows users to request and pay for rides or other services through their 
4  credit card linked Uber account. Through this application, Uber offers various rideshare request 
5  options and has occasionally offered promotional services allowing users to order a free delivery 
6  of cake, doughnuts, or even puppies to their location. In certain major cities, Uber offers an option 
7  called “uberWAV” which enables riders to request a wheelchair accessible vehicle through the 
8  Uber App. Uber does not currently offer uberWAV in New Orleans, Louisiana.  
9    Plaintiffs are persons with disabilities who reside in New Orleans. Both plaintiffs use 
10  electric wheelchairs and rely on public transportation services to get around. While Plaintiffs 
11  would like to use Uber’s transportation service, they cannot because the Uber App does not offer 
12  uberWAV in New Orleans. On October 24, 2017, Uber emailed customers in the New Orleans 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  area about an exclusive show featuring the band Galantis. As explained in Uber’s promotional 
Cif
t al
cC 14  materials, on the day of the show, the Uber App would display an option called “Galantis” which 
i
strof 
Dict  15  would summon a car to take the user to the “secret” location of the concert. Because the Uber App 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  did not allow users to request a wheelchair accessible vehicle, Plaintiffs insist they had no way to 
d Srn 
ee 17  get to the concert. 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Plaintiffs have not downloaded the Uber App because they know it would not allow them 
19  to request a vehicle that could accommodate their electric wheelchairs. If Uber were to offer a ride 
20  service that could accommodate electric wheelchairs, Plaintiffs would attempt to use the service 
21  and participate in Uber’s promotional events. By failing to provide a mechanism to serve 
22  individuals who use electric or otherwise non-foldable wheelchairs, Plaintiffs assert, Uber has 
23  violated its obligations under Title III of the ADA. See 42 U.S.C. §§ 12182, 12184. Plaintiffs seek 
24  declaratory and injunctive relief. 42 U.S.C. § 12188. 
25 
                                                 
26 
1 Except where noted, the facts in this section are drawn from Plaintiffs’ FAC and are taken as true 
27  for the purpose of deciding the motion to dismiss. 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
2 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 3 of 11
 
1  III. LEGAL STANDARD 
2  A complaint must contain “a short and plain statement of the claim showing that the 
3  pleader is entitled to relief.” Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a)(2). While Rule 8 “does not require detailed 
4  factual allegations,” a complaint must have sufficient factual allegations to “state a claim to relief 
5  that is plausible on its face.” Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (citing Bell Atlantic v. 
6  Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 555, 570 (2007)) (internal quotations omitted). A claim is facially 
7  plausible “when the pleaded factual content allows the court to draw the reasonable inference that 
8  the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.” Id. This determination is a context-specific 
9  task requiring the court “to draw on its judicial experience and common sense.” Id. at 679. 
10    A motion to dismiss a complaint under Rule 12(b)(6) tests the legal sufficiency of the 
11  claims alleged in the complaint. See Parks Sch. of Bus., Inc. v. Symington, 51 F.3d 1480, 1484 (9th 
12  Cir. 1995). Dismissal under Rule 12(b)(6) may be based on either the “lack of a cognizable legal 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  theory” or on “the absence of sufficient facts alleged under a cognizable legal theory.” Balistreri v. 
Cif
t al
cC 14  Pacifica Police Dep’t, 901 F.2d 696, 699 (9th Cir. 1990). When evaluating such a motion, the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  court must accept all material allegations in the complaint as true, even if doubtful, and construe 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  them in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Twombly, 550 U.S. at 570. 
d Srn 
ee 17  “[C]onclusory allegations of law and unwarranted inferences,” however, “are insufficient to defeat 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim.” Epstein v. Wash. Energy. Co., 83 F.3d 1136, 1140 
19  (9th Cir. 1996); see also Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555. 
20  IV. DISCUSSION 
21  In a single claim for relief, Plaintiffs allege Uber violated Title III of the ADA under two 
22  independent theories. First, Plaintiffs argue Uber is a specified public transportation service that 
23  discriminates against persons with disabilities by failing to provide wheelchair accessible service, 
24  in violation of section 12184. Second, Plaintiffs contend Uber is operating a place of public 
25  accommodation that similarly discriminates against persons with disabilities, in violation of 
26  section 12182. 
27 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
3 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 4 of 11
 
1  A.  Plaintiffs’ Theories for Relief under 42 U.S.C. § 12184  
2  Section 12184 prohibits discrimination “on the basis of disability in the full and equal 
3  enjoyment of specified public transportation services.” 42 U.S.C. § 12184(a). Under this section, 
discrimination includes failure to: (A) make reasonable modifications consistent with section 
4 
12182(b)(2)(A)(ii); (B) provide auxiliary aids and services consistent with section 
5 
12182(b)(2)(A)(iii); and (C) remove barriers consistent with sections 12182(b)(2)(A) and 
6 
12183(a)(2). 42 U.S.C. § 12184(b)(2).  
7 
1.  Reasonable Modification under Section 12184(b)(2)(A) 
8 
According to Uber, Plaintiffs fail to state a claim under section 12184 because neither of 
9 
them requested a modification of Uber’s polices, practices, or procedures prior to filing suit. 
10 
Under section 12184(b)(2)(A), discrimination is defined as failure to make “reasonable 
11 
modifications” consistent with the requirements of section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii). Furthermore, to 
12 
 a
 rtni prevail under section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii), a plaintiff must show, inter alia, the defendant failed to 
ouor 13 
t Calif make a “requested reasonable modification.” Karczewski v. DCH Mission Valley LLC, 862 F.3d 
cC 14 
i
strof  1006, 1010 (9th Cir. 2017) (quoting Fortyune v. Am. Multi-Cinema, Inc., 364 F.3d 1075, 1082 
Dict  15 
s ri (9th Cir. 2004). As the Central District of California has noted, the precise meaning of “requested” 
et
tatDis 16 
d Srn  is not entirely clear. See Galvez v. Auto. Club of S. Cali., No. SA CV 16-0887-DOC, 2017 WL 
ee 17 
nitrth 4586934, at *4 (C.D. Cal. 2017).  
Uo
N 18 
In Fortyune, a wheelchair-using plaintiff asked the defendant movie theater to remove a 
19 
patron from a designated companion seat so his wife could sit next to him. 364 F.3d at 1078-79. 
20 
The movie theater refused. Id. at 1079. The Ninth Circuit noted that “Fortyune asked both [the 
21 
defendant] and the district court to ensure that he could be seated next to his wife or another 
22 
companion,” Id. at. 1083, creating ambiguity as to whether the term “requested reasonable 
23 
modification” required a pre-suit request or simply referred to the relief sought in the suit itself. 
24 
See Galvez, 2017 WL 4586934, at *4. In Karczewski, a paraplegic plaintiff asked the defendant 
25 
car dealership temporarily to install vehicle hand controls to enable him to test drive a car. 
26 
Karczewski, 862 F.3d at 1007. The dealership refused. Id. There, the court proceeded to discuss 
27 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
4 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 5 of 11
 
1  the reasonableness of the plaintiff’s “requested modification” but did not specifically analyze the 
2  request requirement. 
3  Despite this ambiguity, district courts in the Ninth Circuit have interpreted Karczewski and 
4  Fortyune to require a plaintiff to ask a defendant to change its policy before filing suit. See Razavi 
5  v. Coti, No. 17-cv-04341-BLF, 2018 WL 2867575, at *3 (N.D. Cal. 2018); Galvez, 2017 WL 
6  4586934, at *4; Mannick v. Kaiser Foundation Health Plan, Inc., No. 03-5905-PJH, 2006 WL 
7  2168877, at * 4 (N.D. Cal. 2006). While Plaintiffs need not “say the magic words,” they must 
8  request an accommodation before they claim a defendant has refused to modify its policy, 
9  practices or procedures in violation of 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii). Galvez, 2017 WL 4586934, *4. 
10  The FAC does not allege Plaintiffs requested an accommodation from Uber. Plaintiffs 
11  argue the court can infer the request requirement was satisfied during the mandatory General 
12  Order No. 56 settlement conference between Plaintiffs and Uber. The court, however, is not free to 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  speculate as to a fact not pleaded in the complaint. Rather, the complaint must contain sufficient 
Cif
t al
cC 14  factual allegations to “state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.” Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678. 
i
strof 
Dict  15  Accordingly, Plaintiffs have not pleaded sufficient facts to support their reasonable modification 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  theory under section 12182(b)(2)(A)(ii) via section 12184(b)(2)(A). 
d Srn 
ee 17  2.  All Other Theories for Relief under 42 U.S.C. § 12184 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  While Uber argues Plaintiffs have failed to state a claim under section 12184, it points to 
19  no authority requiring Plaintiffs to make a request for modification prior to suing under the 
20  auxiliary aid provision of section 12184(b)(2)(B), or the removal of barriers provision of section 
21  12184(b)(2)(C). Accordingly, Uber’s motion to dismiss the FAC in its entirety cannot succeed.  
22  B.  Plaintiffs’ Theories for Relief under 42 U.S.C. § 12182 
23  Section 12182 prohibits discrimination on the basis of disability in the equal enjoyment of 
24  the goods and services of a place of public accommodation. 42 U.S.C. § 12182(a). Plaintiffs 
25  advance two arguments under section 12182 in support of their claim. First, Plaintiffs argue 
26  Uber’s rideshare service qualifies as a place of public accommodation and is therefore subject to 
27  section 12182. Alternatively, Plaintiffs contend Uber’s free rideshare service to the Galantis 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
5 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 6 of 11
 
1  concert bears a close “nexus” to the Galantis concert venue and therefore falls under section 
2  12182. 
3  1.  Uber’s Rideshare Service as a Place of Public Accommodation 
4  Section 12181 provides a list of places of public accommodation. 42 U.S.C. § 12181. 
5  Based on these enumerated locales and the principle of noscitur a sociis, the Ninth Circuit has 
6  held that a place of public accommodation must be an “actual, physical place[] where goods or 
7  services are open to the public.” Weyer v. Twentieth Century Fox Film Corp., 198 F.3d 1104, 1114 
8  (9th Cir. 2000). Accordingly, websites are not generally considered places of public 
9  accommodation. See Earll v. eBay, Inc., 599 F. App’x 695, 696 (9th Cir. 2015) (unpublished); 
10  Cullen v. Netflix, 600 Fed. App’x 508, 509 (9th Cir. 2015) (unpublished); see also Young v. 
11  Facebook, 790 F. Supp. 2d 1110, 1115-16 (N.D. Cal. 2011). 
12  Uber argues the Uber App, like a website, is not a physical place and therefore does not 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  qualify as a place of public accommodation. Plaintiffs argue Uber’s business does qualify, namely 
Cif
t al
cC 14  as a “travel service.” 42 U.S.C. § 12181(7)(F). Furthermore, Plaintiffs argue the physical place 
i
strof 
Dict  15  requirement runs contrary to congressional intent that the ADA be broadly construed, Mary Jo C. 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  v. New York State and Local Ret. Sys., 707 F.3d 144, 160 (2d Cir. 2013), and point to First Circuit 
d Srn 
ee 17  precedent holding that a “travel service” can qualify as a place of public accommodation even if it 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  lacks a physical office space, Carparts Distribution Ctr., Inc. v. Auto. Wholesaler’s Ass’n of New 
19  England, 37 F.3d 12, 19 (1st Cir. 1994). Finally, Plaintiffs contend, Uber’s rideshare service 
20  satisfies the physical place requirement in any event because the service sends physical vehicles to 
21  fetch customers and transport them to their desired location in the material world.  
22  While “travel service” is listed as a place of public accommodation under section 
23  12181(7)(F), the Ninth Circuit’s binding precedent limits the term “places of public 
24  accommodation” to “actual, physical places.” Weyer, 198 F.3d at 1114. Neither appeals to 
25  congressional intent nor out-of-circuit caselaw can justify a departure from binding precedent. 
26  Therefore, the question remains whether Uber’s transportation services involve an “actual, 
27  physical place[] where goods or services are open to the public.” See Weyer, 198 F.3d at 1114. 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
6 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 7 of 11
 
1  The fact that Uber sends cars to pick up customers at their desired location and drop them 
2  off at different locations is insufficient to qualify Uber’s rideshare service as a place of public 
3  accommodation. In Weyer, the Ninth Circuit referred to insurance offices and book stores as the 
4  types of places where goods or services were open to the public. See Weyer, 198 F.3d at 1113-14. 
5  Neither the street corner where a customer hails a car-for-hire nor the cars themselves fit in the 
6  same category as the locations contemplated by Weyer. Other district court have similarly held 
7  cars, vans, or other types of vehicles do not qualify as places of public accommodation. See, e.g., 
8  Cottrell v. United Parcel Service, No. 16–1689, 2017 WL 1363307, at * 2 (D.N.J 2017); J.H. by 
9  and through Holman v. Just for Kids, Inc., 248 F. Supp. 3d 1210, 1222 (D. Utah 2017). 
10  Accordingly, Plaintiffs cannot show Uber’s transportation service is a place of public 
11  accommodation. 
12  2.  Discrimination in Uber’s Service of the Galantis Concert 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  According to Plaintiffs, even if Uber’s rideshare service does not qualify as a place of 
Cif
t al
cC 14  public accommodation, it is subject to section 12182 because the lack of wheelchair accessible 
i
strof 
Dict  15  rideshare options prevented Plaintiffs from enjoying the services of a place of public 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  accommodation, i.e. the Galantis concert. Uber advances three counterarguments. First, Uber 
d Srn 
ee 17  contends the Uber App does not bear a close enough nexus to the Galantis concert to give rise to 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  liability. Second, Uber argues Plaintiffs lack standing to claim discrimination with respect to the 
19  Galantis concert venue. Third, Uber argues the FAC lacks sufficient facts showing Uber operated 
20  the Galantis concert venue. 
21  a.  The Nexus Between Uber’s Rideshare Service and the Galantis Concert 
22  The protections of section 12182 are not limited to the four walls of a place of 
23  accommodation. Rather, section 12182 forbids discrimination in the services of a place of public 
24  accommodation, not just the services offered in the place of public accommodation. 42 U.S.C. 
25  § 12182(a). Thus, the protections of section 12182 may apply where there is nexus between the 
26  service at issue and the physical place of public accommodation. Weyer, 198 F.3d at 1114. In 
27  Weyer, the insurance policy purchased by the plaintiff through his employer did not bear a 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
7 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 8 of 11
 
1  sufficiently close nexus to the physical insurance office to give rise to a claim under section 
2  12182. Id. at 114-15. By contrast, the decision whether to install ramps or elevators to enable 
3  disabled persons to get into an insurance office is closely related to the physical place of public 
4  accommodation. See id. 
5  Applying this rule, the district court in National Fed.’n of the Blind v. Target Corp. held 
6  there was a sufficient nexus between Target.com and the physical Target stores because the 
7  website was “heavily integrated” with, and served as a gateway to, the stores. 452 F. Supp. 2d 946, 
8  955 (N.D. Cal. 2006). In particular, the Target website allowed customers to refill prescriptions, 
9  order photo prints to pick up at the store, print coupons to redeem at the store, purchase many of 
10  the items offered in the store, and find information about store hours and locations. Id. at 949. By 
11  contrast, in Stern v. Sony Corp. of Am., the Ninth Circuit held the plaintiff’s inability to enjoy a 
12  video game due to his disability did not have a sufficient nexus with a marketing event associated 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  with the game. 459 Fed. App’x 609, 611 (9th Cir. 2011) (unpublished). 
Cif
t al
cC 14  Plaintiffs argue Uber’s rideshare service bears a close nexus to the Galantis concert venue 
i
strof 
Dict  15  because it was the only way to get to the secret concert location. According to Plaintiffs, this 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  presents an even more compelling case than does Target because Uber was “quite literally the 
d Srn 
ee 17  physical gatekeeper of the concert.” Opp. Mot. Dismiss 15. Uber argues Stern is more instructive, 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  where the nexus between the purportedly inaccessible video game and a promotional event for the 
19  video game was too tenuous. Uber further contends the Galantis concert is better characterized as 
20  a benefit of using Uber, rather than Uber’s rideshare being considered a service of the Galantis 
21  concert. 
22  Practices that prevent disabled persons from physically accessing places of public 
23  accommodation are precisely the sort of activities Weyer described as closely related to a physical 
24  place of public accommodation. Weyer, 198 F.3d at 1114. Furthermore, like in Target, the Uber 
25  App and rideshare service are functioning as a gateway to the Galantis concert venue. Without 
26  access to Uber’s rideshare services, it would be difficult, if not impossible, for Plaintiffs to enjoy 
27  the goods and services offered at the physical Galantis concert venue. Uber’s comparison to Stern 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
8 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 9 of 11
 
1  is inapposite. In Stern, the plaintiff alleged he was unable to enjoy fully the marketing event 
2  because the video game itself was inaccessible, yet, he never claimed he was prevented from 
3  gaining entry to the marketing event due to his disability. According to the FAC and attached 
4  exhibits, Uber’s rideshare service was the only means of gaining access to the Galantis concert. 
5  Therefore Plaintiffs have plausibly alleged Uber’s rideshare service to the Galantis concert bears a 
6  sufficiently close nexus to the physical location to fall within the ambit of section 12182. 
7  b.  Plaintiffs’ Standing with Respect to the Galantis Promotional Concert  
8  Plaintiffs seek injunctive relief under § 12188. To have standing to seek such relief, 
9  Plaintiffs must plausibly allege a “real and immediate threat of repeated injury” in the future. 
10  Chapman v. Pier 1 Imports, Inc., 631 F.3d 939, 946 (9th Cir. 2011). Plaintiffs’ FAC alleges only 
11  one concert hosted by Uber which they were unable to attend due to lack of wheelchair accessible 
12  options—the Galantis concert. In their opposition to the motion to dismiss, Plaintiffs mention two 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  other parties hosted by Uber in the New Orleans area. Plaintiffs assert that they would participate 
Cif
t al
cC 14  in Uber’s promotional events and use Uber’s other services if these events and services were made 
i
strof 
Dict  15  accessible. 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  A single promotional event does not show a real and immediate prospect that Uber will 
d Srn 
ee 17  host more “secret” events which Plaintiffs will be unable to attend. The two other promotional 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  parties mentioned in Plaintiffs’ opposition to the motion to dismiss were not discussed in the FAC 
19  and therefore cannot be considered. Furthermore, Plaintiffs cannot plausible claim they want to 
20  attend Uber’s future promotional events without at least establishing the nature or subject of these 
21  activities. Accordingly, the FAC does not allege sufficient facts to show Plaintiffs plausibly have 
22  standing to seek injunctive relief with respect to Uber’s rideshare service to the Galantis concert. 
23  c.  Whether Uber Operated the Galantis Concert Venue 
24  Even if Plaintiffs had standing with respect to Uber’s rideshare service to the Galantis 
25  concert, the FAC does not plausibly allege Uber operated the Galantis concert venue. The anti-
discrimination provisions of section 12182 only apply to an entity that “owns, leases (or leases to), 
26 
or operates a place of public accommodation.” 42 U.S.C. § 12182(a). In this context, the term 
27 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO DISMISS 
CASE NO.  17-cv-06124-RS 
9 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 84   Filed 10/03/18   Page 10 of 11
 
1  “operate” means to keep in operation, control or direct the functioning of, conduct the affairs of, or 
2  to manage. Pickern v. Pier 1 Imports, 457 F.3d 963, 966 (9th Cir. 2006). A person may 
temporarily operate a place of public accommodation if the party exercises sufficient control over 
3 
the venue and the configuration of facilities with regard to accessibility. Disabled Rights Action 
4 
Comm. v. Las Vegas Events, Inc., 375 F.3d 861, 878 (9th Cir. 2004). 
5 
Plaintiffs’ FAC alleges Uber “hosted” a secret concert featuring the band Galantis and 
6 
therefore operated a place of public accommodation. FAC ¶ 77-80. Plaintiffs, however, provide no 
7 
facts indicating Uber controlled the concert venue or facilities, as required under the definition of 
8 
the term “to operate.” The allegation Uber “hosted” a concert, without more, is insufficient to 
9 
support a reasonable inference that Uber operated the Galantis concert.  
10 
C.  Leave to Amend 
11 
If a court dismisses a complaint, it “should grant leave to amend even if no request to 
12 
 a
 ourtorni 13  amend the pleading was made, unless it determines the pleading could not possibly be cured by 
Cif
t al the allegation of other facts.” Lopez v. Smith, 203 F.3d 1122, 1127 (9th Cir. 2000). In making this 
cC 14 
i
strof 
Dict  15  determination, the court should consider such factors as “the presence or absence of undue delay, 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  bad faith, dilatory motive, repeated failure to cure deficiencies by previous amendments, undue 
d Srn  prejudice to the opposing party and futility of the proposed amendment.” See Moore v. Kayport 
ee 17 
th
nirt
Uo Package Express, 885 F.2d 531, 538 (9th Cir. 1989). 
N 18 
The FAC and the briefing related to this motion to dismiss do not indicate bad faith on the 
19 
part of Plaintiffs. Furthermore, this is the first motion to dismiss entertained in this suit. While it is 
20 
not apparent Plaintiff will be able to plead adequately all the theories advanced in the FAC, leave 
21 
to amend is granted. 
22 
V. CONCLUSION 
23 
For the foregoing reasons, Uber’s motion to dismiss is granted in part and denied in part. 
24 
In particular, Plaintiffs’ claim survives under the auxiliary aid provision of section 12184(b)(2)(B) 
25 
and the removal of barriers provision of section 12184(b)(2)(C). All other theories are dismissed 
26 
with leave to amend. If Plaintiffs elect to file an amended complaint consistent with this order, 
27

STEPHAN NAMISNAK, et al., 
10  Case No. 17-cv-06124-RS   
Plaintiffs,   
11   
v.  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND

i
strof     
Dict  15   
s ri
et
tatDis 16  I. INTRODUCTION 
d Srn 
ee 17  Defendants Uber Technologies Inc. and Raiser, LLC (collectively “Uber”) move to compel 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  arbitration of all claims asserted by plaintiffs Stephan Namisnak, Francis Falls, and Mitchell 
19  Miraglia. Pursuant to Civil Local Rule 7-1(b), the motion is suitable for disposition without oral 
20  argument, and the hearing set for April 19, 2018, is vacated. For the reasons that follow, the 
21  motion is granted as to claims asserted by Miraglia and denied as to claims asserted by Namisnak 
22  and Falls.  
23  II. BACKGROUND 
24  Namisnak, Falls, and Miraglia are persons with disabilities who live in New Orleans, 
25  Louisiana. As a result of their physical limitations, they are dependent on electric wheelchairs for 
26  mobility. One service they cannot utilize is Uber’s ride-sharing service, which allows mobile 
27  phone app users to call a car to get from one place to another. Because the Uber App in New 
28  Orleans does not provide an option for riders to call a wheelchair-accessible vehicle, plaintiffs are 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 2 of 7
 
1  unable to use the service. Accordingly, plaintiffs allege, Uber has violated its obligations under the 
2  Americans with Disabilities Act (“ADA”), the California Disabled Persons Act (“CDPA”), and 
3  the California Unfair Competition law (“UCL”).  
4  When customers sign up to use Uber’s services, they must first create an account using the 
5  Uber App. The app user’s registration page displays the phrase, “by creating an uber account, you 
6  agree to our terms & conditions and privacy policy,” which is hyperlinked so the registrant may 
7  view the agreement. Creating an account requires the customer to accept Uber’s terms and 
8  conditions, including a mandatory arbitration provision.  
9  In 2016, Miraglia used a smartphone to access the Uber App and create a rider account. As 
10  part of the registration process, as described above, Miraglia was required to agree to Uber’s terms 
11  and conditions and privacy policy. Uber asserts that Miraglia is bound by the terms of that 
12  agreement and must submit his claims to arbitration pursuant to its arbitration provision.  
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  Falls and Namisnak never downloaded the Uber App or created an Uber account. As a 
Cif
t al
cC 14  consequence, neither plaintiff manifested agreement to Uber’s terms and conditions or had the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  opportunity to review any provisions contained therein. Nonetheless, Uber argues that because 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  plaintiffs rely upon Uber’s terms and conditions in bringing this action, they are equitably 
d Srn 
ee 17  estopped from challenging the agreement’s arbitration requirement.  
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  III. LEGAL STANDARD 
19  Uber’s terms and conditions agreement is “a contract evidencing a transaction involving 
20  commerce” subject to the Federal Arbitration Act (“FAA”). 9 U.S.C. § 2; Chiron Corp. v. Ortho 
21  Diagnostic Sys., Inc., 207 F.3d 1126, 1130 (9th Cir. 2000). “The FAA provides that any arbitration 
22  agreement within its scope ‘shall be valid, irrevocable, and enforceable,’ . . . and permits a party 
23  ‘aggrieved by the alleged . . . refusal of another to arbitrate’ to petition any federal district court 
24  for an order compelling arbitration in the manner provided for in the agreement.” Chiron, 207 
25  F.3d at 1130 (quoting 9 U.S.C. § 4) (second omission in original). The FAA “leaves no place for 
26  the exercise of discretion by a district court, but instead mandates that district courts shall direct 
27  the parties to proceed to arbitration on issues as to which an arbitration agreement has been 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
2 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 3 of 7
 
1  signed.” Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. v. Byrd, 470 U.S. 213, 218 (1985) (citing 9 U.S.C. §§ 3, 4). 
2  The role of a district court under the FAA “is therefore limited to determining (1) whether a valid 
3  agreement to arbitrate exists and, if it does, (2) whether the agreement encompasses the dispute at 
4  issue.” Chiron, 207 F.3d at 1130 (internal citations omitted). “If the response is affirmative on 
5  both counts, then the [FAA] requires the court to enforce the arbitration agreement in accordance 
6  with its terms.” Id. 
7  IV. DISCUSSION 
8  “Before a party to a lawsuit can be ordered to arbitrate . . . there should be an express, 
9  unequivocal agreement to that effect. Only when there is no genuine issue of fact concerning the 
10  formation of the agreement should the court decide as a matter of law that the parties did or did not 
11  enter into such an agreement.” Three Valleys Mun. Water Dist. v. E.F. Hutton & Co., 925 F.2d 1136, 
12  1141 (9th Cir. 1991) (internal quotations omitted). In deciding whether there is a genuine issue of fact 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  concerning formation of an agreement, the party opposing arbitration shall receive “the benefit of all 
Cif
t al
cC 14  reasonable doubts and inferences.” Id. (internal quotations omitted). “When deciding whether the 
i
strof 
Dict  15  parties agreed to arbitrate a certain matter . . . courts generally . . . should apply ordinary state-law 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  principles that govern the formation of contracts.” First Options of Chicago, Inc. v. Kaplan, 514 U.S. 
d Srn 
ee 17  938, 944 (1995). Under California law, mutual assent is the key to contract formation. See Binder v. 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  Aetna Life Ins. Co., 75 Cal. App. 4th 832, 850 (Ct. App. 1999). In the context of an electronic 
19  consumer transaction, the occurrence of mutual assent ordinarily turns on whether the consumer had 
20  reasonable notice of a merchant’s terms of service agreement. See, e.g., Nguyen v. Barnes & Noble 
21  Inc., 763 F.3d 1171, 1173 (9th Cir. 2014) (“We agree with the district court that Barnes & Noble did 
22  not provide reasonable notice of its Terms of Use, and that Nguyen therefore did not unambiguously 
23  manifest assent to the arbitration provision contained therein.”). 
24  The parties do not dispute that the appearance of a terms and services link on the Uber App 
25  registration screen provided sufficient notice of the arbitration agreement. Rather, Namisnak and Falls 
26  deny being bound by an arbitration agreement to which they did not assent, seeing as neither plaintiff 
27  ever downloaded the Uber App or had the opportunity to review its terms and conditions. Miraglia 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
3 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 4 of 7
 
1  contends that although he initially agreed to Uber’s terms and conditions, the arbitration provision is 
2  unenforceable against him because he deleted the Uber App. In the alternative, he argues that he 
3  cannot be compelled to submit his claims to arbitration because the defendants named in this action 
4  were not parties to the terms and conditions contract. 
5  A.  Falls and Namisnak 
6  Generally, parties who have not assented to an arbitration agreement cannot be compelled 
to arbitrate under its terms. E.E.O.C. v. Waffle House, 534 U.S. 279, 293 (2002); Volt Info. Sci., 
7 
Inc. v. Bd. of Tr. of Leland Stanford Junior Univ., 489 U.S. 468, 478 (1989) (“the FAA does not 
8 
require parties to arbitrate when they have not agreed to do so”). Having never downloaded the 
9 
Uber App, Falls and Namisnak lacked notice of Uber’s terms and conditions, including its 
10 
embedded arbitration provision, and never manifested their intention to be bound.  
11 
Nevertheless, Uber argues that Falls and Namisnak are subject to the arbitration agreement 
12 
 a
 rtni as a matter of California substantive law. “[S]ubstantive federal law [governs] the enforceability of 
ouor 13 
Cif
t al arbitration agreements” but does not “purport[] to alter background principles of state contract law 
cC 14 
i
Distrct of  15  regarding the scope of agreements (including the question of who is bound by them).” Arthur 
s ri
tateDist 16  Anderson LLP v. Carlisle, 556 U.S. 624, 630 (2009). According to Uber, plaintiffs are precluded 
d Srn  from refusing to arbitrate by the doctrine of equitable estoppel, which permits enforcement of an 
ee 17 
th
Uniort arbitration agreement against a nonsignatory under certain circumstances. Id. at 631. In California, 
N 18 
“[w]hen a plaintiff brings a claim which relies on contract terms against a defendant, the plaintiff 
19 
may be equitably estopped from repudiating the arbitration clause contained in that agreement.” 
20 
JSM Tuscany, LLC v. Superior Court, 123 Cal. Rptr. 3d 429, 443 (Ct. App. 2011). “When that 
21 
plaintiff is suing on a contract—on the basis that, even though the plaintiff was not a party to the 
22 
contract, the plaintiff is nonetheless entitled to recover for its breach, the plaintiff should be 
23 
equitably estopped from repudiating the contract’s arbitration clause.” Id. When determining 
24 
whether equitable estoppel is appropriate, courts must look to the nature of the claims being 
25 
asserted to determine whether they are “intimately founded in and intertwined with the underlying 
26 
contract obligations.” Id. at 442-43. 
27 
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS 
4 

Case 3:17-cv-06124-RS   Document 49   Filed 04/13/18   Page 5 of 7
 
1  As Uber views it, plaintiffs’ standing to sue is based on allegations that they would have 
2  used the Uber App but for Uber’s discriminatory policies. Had Falls and Namisnak downloaded 
3  and used the Uber App, they would have been required to agree to Uber’s terms and conditions, 
4  including the arbitration provision. Therefore, Uber reasons, plaintiffs necessarily rely on the 
5  agreement in bringing this suit and should be equitably estopped from avoiding its obligations. 
6  This argument is unpersuasive. The fact that Uber’s terms and conditions are implicated in the 
7  averments of the complaint does not by itself indicate that plaintiffs are claiming some privilege or 
8  benefit derived from Uber’s terms and conditions, or that they are seeking to use the terms and 
9  conditions against Uber.  
10  The purpose of equitable estoppel is to prevent parties from invoking the terms of a 
11  contract as the basis for suit while avoiding a corresponding contractual obligation to arbitrate. 
12  Goldman v. KPMG LLP, 92 Cal. Rptr. 3d 534, 543-44 (Ct. App. 2009). “The linchpin for 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  equitable estoppel is equity—fairness,” and “the application of the doctrine is fact-specific.” Id. at 
Cif
t al
cC 14  555 (internal quotations omitted) (quoting Grigson v. Creative Artists, LLC, 210 F.3d 524, 528 
i
strof 
Dict  15  (5th Cir. 2000). Falls and Namisnak assert claims against Uber based on rights created by the 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  ADA, which are not dependent upon or bound up in the terms and obligations of Uber’s service 
d Srn 
ee 17  agreement. It is Uber’s alleged refusal to comply with the requirements of the ADA, not the 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  requirements of its consumer agreements, which form the basis of this lawsuit. See Goldman 92 
19  Cal. Rptr. 3d at 543 (holding that plaintiff signatories were not equitably estopped from refusing to 
20  arbitrate under the terms of an agreement because their “allegations depend solely on the actions 
21  of [defendant nonsignatories], not on the terms of the operating agreements, for their success.”). 
22  Therefore, it does not offend the principles of equity and fairness to conclude that Uber’s 
23  arbitration agreement is not binding upon Falls and Namisnak.  
24  Uber cannot use its consumer arbitration agreements so expansively as to block all 
25  prospective ADA plaintiffs from seeking relief in federal court. Because Falls and Namisnak never 
26  agreed to arbitrate claims against Uber and are not equitably estopped from refusing to do so, 
27  Uber’s motion to compel arbitration is denied as to their claims.  
28  ORDER GRANTING IN PART AND DENYING IN PART MOTION TO COMPEL ARBITRATION 
CASE NO. 17-cv-06124-RS

1  B.  Miraglia 
2  Unlike Falls and Namisnak, Miraglia does not deny agreeing to Uber’s terms and conditions 
3  when he created an Uber account. Instead, Miraglia contends that he rescinded the agreement by 
4  deleting the Uber App, rendering the agreement’s arbitration clause unenforceable against him. In 
5  response, Uber argues that rescission is an issue of disputed fact that must itself be arbitrated, for 
6  “unless the challenge is to the arbitration clause itself, the issue of the contract’s validity is considered 
7  by the arbitrator in the first instance.” Buckeye Check Cashing, Inc. v. Cardegna, 546 U.S. 440, 445-46 
8  (2006). Because Miraglia asserts a challenge to the validity of his contract with Uber, not the validity 
9  of the specific arbitration provision contained therein, the question of rescission must go to arbitration. 
10  Alternatively, Miraglia claims that Uber Technologies, Inc. and Raiser, LLC cannot enforce 
11  the arbitration provision against him because they are not parties to the terms and conditions 
12  agreement. The agreement purports to create a contract between the Uber App user and “Uber USA, 
 a
 rtni
ouor 13  LLC and its subsidiaries and affiliates (collectively ‘Uber’).” In California, “[a] corporation is an 
Cif
t al ‘affiliate’ of, or a corporation is ‘affiliated’ with, another specified corporation if it directly, or 
cC 14 
i
strof 
Dict  15  indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, is controlled by or is under common 
s ri
tateDist 16  control with the other specified corporation.” Cal. Corp. Code § 150.1 Uber explains that Uber 
d Srn  Technologies, Inc. is the parent company that controls Uber USA, LLC and Raiser, LLC. Thus, 
ee 17 
th
nirt Uber Technologies, Inc. and Raiser, LLC are affiliates of Uber USA, LLC, and parties to the 
Uo
N 18 
arbitration agreement embedded in Uber’s terms and conditions.  
19 
Miraglia asserts that defendants in this matter are not affiliated with Uber USA, LLC, 
20 
because that entity does not appear on Uber’s certification of interested entities. See Dkt. No. 12. 
21 
The Federal Rules, however, only require Uber to disclose a parent or controlling entity. See Fed. 
22 
R. Civ. Proc. 7.1. Because Uber Technologies, Inc. is the parent company, it was not required to 
23 
disclose Uber USA, LLC. The relevant local rules require disclosure of any entity which has “(i) a 
24 
financial interest of any kind in the subject matter in controversy or in a party to the proceeding; or 
25 
                                                 
26

27  Exh. 1 § 7.

1  (ii) any other kind of interest that could be substantially affected by the outcome of the 
2  proceeding.” Civ. Loc. R. 3-15. Uber denies that Uber USA, LLC has a financial interest or any 
other kind of interest that might be affected by the outcome of this litigation, and Miraglia has 
3 
pointed to no evidence indicating otherwise. Therefore, the failure to list Uber USA, LLC on the 
4 
certification disclosure does not demonstrate that Uber USA, LLC, Uber Technologies, Inc., and 
5 
Raiser, LLC are not affiliates who are all parties to the arbitration agreement that binds Miraglia.  
6 
Not only is the arbitration agreement enforceable against Miraglia, his ADA dispute with 
7 
Uber is within the scope of the agreement. The 2016 terms and services arbitration agreement, 
8 
which was in effect when Miraglia created his Uber account, is drafted broadly to cover “any 
9 
dispute, claim or controversy arising out of or relating to these Terms or the breach, termination, 
10 
enforcement, interpretation or validity thereof or the use of the Services.” Barajas Decl. Exh. 1 § 6 
11 
(emphasis added). Miraglia’s ADA claim, which arises out of his inability to access and use 
12 
 a
 rtni Uber’s transportation services, is within the scope of the agreement. Accordingly, Uber’s motion 
ouor 13 
Cif to compel arbitration of Miraglia’s claims is granted.
